And slightly further away, here‚Äôs the Quaggy making its way to @Sutcliffe_Park üåä @EnvAgency https://t.co/7Cm04HypC1

tweets.text:
@stuartpengs @ProfJGrey @WildTroutTrust @YorkDalesRT @EnvAgencyYNE @Jack_Hirst3 @YWT_North @BiodiversityEA @EAGeomorphology @SandTCUKYorks Can‚Äôt continue this tonight, but will come back to this 1 ‚Ä¶because based on my own observations over past 10yrs in Tay catchment I strongly disagree with your assertion that beavers can thrive without meaningful action to address other river ills. TBC? 
G‚Äôd night & üôè for chatüçÄ

@_Polinard @ProfJGrey @WildTroutTrust @YorkDalesRT @EnvAgencyYNE @Jack_Hirst3 @YWT_North @BiodiversityEA @EAGeomorphology @SandTCUKYorks One thing we need to be very cautious of Andrew; for the most part beaver are impervious to many of the issues currently impacting on our rivers in UK, and have demonstrated their ability to thrive even with no meaningful action in addressing those issues 1/2

@_Polinard @ProfJGrey @WildTroutTrust @YorkDalesRT @EnvAgencyYNE @Jack_Hirst3 @YWT_North @BiodiversityEA @EAGeomorphology @SandTCUKYorks We are in very dangerous territory when the metric for a healthy river is based on its beaver population and very little else (anecdotes not withstanding). Beaver's should be the final piece of the jigsaw, but they're being marketed as the only one needed and that is reckless.

@_Polinard @ProfJGrey @WildTroutTrust @YorkDalesRT @EnvAgencyYNE @Jack_Hirst3 @YWT_North @BiodiversityEA @EAGeomorphology @SandTCUKYorks It depends on whether there's a net positive/negative as far as the rest of their life strategies (i.e. obstructing migration). If they didn't build dams then I'd say yes, but it's far more complex than that. Though current denuded riparian buffer is an issue not fixed by beaver.

@ProfJGrey @WildTroutTrust @YorkDalesRT @EnvAgencyYNE @Jack_Hirst3 @YWT_North @BiodiversityEA @EAGeomorphology @SandTCUKYorks #beavers are surely the best agents of natural wood fall, They have the skills to position it perfectly and with great efficiency. Much more reliable than depending on the random chance of decay or windthrow. ?
@stuartpengs

With salmonid spawning season curtailing in-river works, it's now time to walk & talk @WildTroutTrust  Advisory Visits.
1st up, the Crimple... Silt central! Natural woodfall partial pinches of the channel vital to expose gravel & kickstart sinuosity
#WoodIsGood #geomorphology https://t.co/PVjQgwbBGy

tweets.text: What a surprise! It rains in London, cue @thameswater to pump untreated shit into the Thames. And no sanction from our glorious steward of nature, the @envagency https://t.co/JaWrLdXy2o

Overnight rain of biblical proportions and this morning the upper reaches of the Ivel are swollen with run off from the fields. Don‚Äôt be fooled into thinking this is groundwater the springs are still pitiful @AquiferChalk @EnvAgency @AffinityWater https://t.co/kZ6zV4XVUJ

@RTFphotos @BeaverTrust @ninaconstable @sophiepavs @jaowallace @NatureTrustEU @HFFnature @kernowbeaver @gow_derek @rcampbellpalmer @fishinguideuk @DefraGovUK @Lukesteele4 @slowtheflow_UK @treesponsibilit @CrownTrees @YorkshireiCASP @EnvAgencyYNE @ScottAPatient Thanks @RTFphotos for the tag - it's definitely something we are interested in and may have future relevance to the #caldervalley (which for those who aren't familiar is heavily affected by flooding). We will try to make the screening and if not we will watch the recording.
Meanwhile, the lovely sloshy trickle through the field I walked earlier, where the source of this river moved uphill by about quarter of a mile, ended in this! Thread! https://t.co/xY9o6403jJ
